abstract: President Obama held Silvio Berlusconi at arm's length for three years, treating Italy's flamboyant prime minister - he of the bunga bunga parties and the well-parsed sexual exploits - with a somewhat frozen correctness. The new prime minister, Mario Monti, a sudden darling of the international stage, is widely seen as a tough economist and a staid European bureaucrat with no apparent skeletons in the closet. Signore Monti is now getting the full-court press in Washington, and the hottest ticket in town this week is a dinner with him at the glittering Villa Firenze, home to the Italian ambassador. On Thursday, Mr. Obama will hold talks with Mr. Monti at the White House.

headline.main: Washington Says 'Benvenuto' to Italy's New Leader
